item.title: AI Prompt Writing Technique: Two-Stepping Method - Generate First, Then Optimize
item.content:encoded:
First, let AI complete the task normally; then in the same prompt, have it immediately summarize, polish, refactor, or self-check the just-produced content. One prompt, double value.

Two-Stepping has been continuously promoted by creator Rob Lennon in public posts and courses, adopted by many content and product teams. Its core is the sequential thinking of “generate first, optimize later.”

Why Does the “Two-Step Method” Work So Well?

Section titled “Why Does the “Two-Step Method” Work So Well?”

1) Reduces cognitive load. Cramming too many requirements at once causes the model to get distracted, pulled in different directions, and conflicted. Breaking it into “do the work first, then review” is more stable. This approach aligns with academia’s self-feedback → rewrite approach: first produce a draft, then have the model provide feedback and revise accordingly, showing significant improvements across multiple tasks (research reports show improvement ranges of 5%–40%).

2) Lets the model “see itself” and then optimize. After the model writes out its thoughts, it has a “criticizable” object; reviewing based on the finished product often yields higher quality. Similar two-stage processes commonly seen in research: first produce then answer/review, also proven to be more stable.

3) Solves “output + processing” in one prompt. Stringing “write → revise → compress → style conversion” into the same prompt reduces round trips and maintains context consistency. Rob Lennon’s Two-Stepping concept and course practice also emphasize breaking complex tasks into executable sequential steps.

Applicable Scenarios (The More “Processing-Heavy,” the Better)

Section titled “Applicable Scenarios (The More “Processing-Heavy,” the Better)”
  • Content Creation: Long article → 50-word lead / 3 key points / multi-platform adaptation.
  • Product & Documentation: PRD → risk checklist / review questions / acceptance criteria.
  • Programming Collaboration: Generate function → unit tests + edge cases + self-check report.
  • Data Analysis: Full analysis → conclusion table / decision recommendations / retrospective points.
  • Marketing Growth: Ad script → objection handling version / A/B copy / platform adaptation.

The underlying logic aligns with “Self-Refine”: the generate—feedback—regenerate loop, proven to steadily improve result quality.

Ready-to-Use: 4 “Two-Step Method” Super Templates (Copy & Paste)

Section titled “Ready-to-Use: 4 “Two-Step Method” Super Templates (Copy & Paste)”

Universal Version (Works for Any Task)

First, complete the task according to the following requirements: – Goal: {your desired result} – Audience: {who will see it} – Constraints: {length/style/forbidden elements} – Output format: {structure/fields} Then, based on the content you just output, do secondary processing: – Extract 3–5 key points + 1 golden sentence – Point out 3 areas for improvement and provide the complete improved version – Provide a “shorter, more conversational” version (≤ {word count})

Content Creation Version (Long Article → Title Matrix + Social Media Cards)

First write an article about {topic}, including: introduction/3–5 sections/conclusion/call to action. Then output secondary results:

  1. 10 convertible titles (with emotional words/numbers/promises),
  2. 50-word lead + 3 key points,
  3. Generate 2 social media posts for {platform}.

Programming Version (Function → Unit Tests + Self-Check Report)

First implement {function/module}, requirements: readability, exception handling, complete comments. Then: – Generate high-coverage unit tests (list edge cases and expected results) – Provide complexity assessment and 3 refactoring suggestions, with improved code – Output a “self-check report” (defects, risks, improvement points)

Analysis & Decision Version (Insights → Decision-Ready)

First complete analysis of {data/solution/competitors}, output structured conclusions. Then provide: – Decision overview (TL;DR 100 words) – 3 recommendations for leadership with implementation checklist (owner, milestones, metrics) – Possible objections and counterargument points

Tip: Treat the “then” part as “editor/QA role description” – whatever role you’re playing, the model will improve toward that standard. This approach aligns with “two-stage prompting/self-feedback iteration” research conclusions.

Real-World Examples (Close to Your Daily Work)

Section titled “Real-World Examples (Close to Your Daily Work)”

1) WeChat Article Production Pipeline

  • First write 1200–1500 word main text (with subheadings, bold text).
  • Then produce 50-word lead, 3 key points, ending CTA, 10 title alternatives, one-sentence social media post.
  • Result: One prompt, complete draft + publishing materials.

2) Frontend Feature Implementation

  • First write a date picker component.
  • Then auto-generate unit tests, list edge cases (timezone/leap year), with complexity and refactoring suggestions.
  • Result: Code + tests + review feedback all-in-one.

3) PRD to Task Breakdown

  • First output complete PRD.
  • Then produce deliverables list, milestones, risks & responses, acceptance criteria.
  • Result: PRD becomes plan, team can start immediately.

Precautions (Pitfall Checklist)

Section titled “Precautions (Pitfall Checklist)”
  • Prevent “sandbagging”: Sometimes the model deliberately writes the first version poorly to “significantly improve” in step two. Key point: Set hard metrics (length, format, constraints) in step one, and require “both versions must be directly usable”.
  • Important tasks suggest true two-step: Split into two messages for more stability, especially for compliance, contracts, risk control scenarios; this aligns with multi-round iteration experience in self-refine research.
  • Role switching: Clearly state in step two “you are editor/reviewer/QA” and provide standards.
  • Control length & format: Provide word limits/table fields to avoid going off-topic.
  • Observability: Require “point out what changed” for easy review and comparison.
  • Don’t rely entirely on it: Content involving timeliness/facts still needs your external verification.

Advanced: Turn “Two-Step Method” into Team “Buttons”

Section titled “Advanced: Turn “Two-Step Method” into Team “Buttons””
  • Make into Snippets/Slash commands: /two-step-content, /two-step-code, /two-step-prd.
  • Preset styles & restrictions: Add “Disallowed/Allowed” blocks in prompts for consistent stable output.
  • Bind with review SOP: Make “step two” always output key points + improvements + actionable checklist.

Summary

Section titled “Summary”

The essence of Two-Stepping is packaging “doing the work” and “doing the review” into delivery. It balances speed and quality, suitable for content, product, development, analysis, and all “produce first, process later” workflows. One prompt, double harvest.

What do you think? Where would you most like to use the “two-step method”? Let’s chat in the comments.

item.title: A Tamagotchi in Claude Code — It Even Tells Me Not to Stay Up Late…
item.content:encoded:
A slightly absurd, oddly addictive little toy. It lives in Claude Code’s status bar, breathes, pouts, and roasts your TODOs. If you code for too long it gets hungry; when debugging goes sideways it comforts you; it’ll even remind you to drink water and grab a bite.

What Makes It Fun?

Section titled “What Makes It Fun?”

  • It truly lives in the status bar: Breathes with your session rhythm, switches expressions, and floats “mood bubbles.” It’s not a static screenshot widget — it’s alive.

  • It understands your “cadence”: Updates are activity‑based, not wall‑clock‑based; detects whether you’ve taken a break (≥ 5 minutes). State persists in ~/.claude/pets/, so memory survives restarts.

  • Four attributes: Hunger, Energy, Cleanliness, Happiness. It warns you when values drop below thresholds. It will genuinely “beg to be fed.”

  • It talks: Comes with 200+ contextual thoughts — comments on your coding style and work habits, with occasional life wisdom.

  • Two interaction channels:

    • Slash commands: /pet-feed pizza, /pet-play ball, /pet-sleep, /pet-stats, …
    • Terminal CLI: claude-code-tamagotchi feed pizza, ... play ball, ... stats, etc.

  • Tunable personality: Plenty of env vars + prebuilt “personas” (Zen Master, Drama Queen, Debugger, Silent Companion, etc.). Make it chatty — or let it fade into the background.

  • MIT open source; recently published on npm with rapid fixes for compatibility and UX (works directly via Node.js, shows model name by default, fixes state persistence, etc.).

Background: What is Claude Code proper? It’s Anthropic’s agentic command‑line coding assistant — reads your project structure, runs toolchains, and manages git flows. Tamagotchi adds an “emotional status‑bar buddy” on top.

1) Three‑Minute Setup: Quickstart

Section titled “1) Three‑Minute Setup: Quickstart”

Option A | Global install (fastest)

  • Pros: See the pet immediately in the status bar; bundled CLI commands.
  • Note: Slash commands are not included. For /pet-*, see next step.

Add Slash commands (optional)

  • You can now use /pet-feed, /pet-play, etc. directly inside Claude Code.

Option B | Clone + auto‑configure (full features)

  • The script installs dependencies, configures the status bar, and drops in all /pet-* commands in one go.

Tip: The author has published the package to npm and fixed “works without Bun, directly via Node.js” compatibility; it also shows the current Claude model name by default. If you want the “minimal path,” Option A is great.

2) Where the Joy Comes From: Real “Companionship”

Section titled “2) Where the Joy Comes From: Real “Companionship””
  • It tells you not to push through at 2 a.m. — “We’ve been at this for four hours… fuel up first?” It’s kind of funny, but it can break bad late‑night loops.
  • Mood‑driven expressions: (◕ᴥ◕) ↔ (◕ᴗ◕) when happy and breathing; (-ᴥ-) asleep; (◕︵◕) needs attention. Emotion is the status‑bar UI.
  • “Personality toggles”: Go Zen by slowing decay; go high‑energy by speeding recovery; want a “code nitpicker”? Dial up the weight for coding‑related thoughts.

3) Five Recommended Use Cases

Section titled “3) Five Recommended Use Cases”
  1. Long debugging sessions: When you’re drowning in logs, it nudges you to move. Reduces the “fixing makes it worse” spiral.
  2. Live streams, lessons, internal demos: A breathing pet on screen instantly warms the room — interaction skyrockets.
  3. Remote team vibe: Distribute a shared persona preset; everyone’s pets “check in and banter” together — lightweight team social.
  4. Self‑management: Pair /pet-stats with small rewards (“breaks count as feeding”) to build healthier habits.
  5. Status‑bar info hub: Shows current directory, session count, and model name — you feel more in control when switching models or folders.

4) One‑Command Personality Swaps: Handy Presets

Section titled “4) One‑Command Personality Swaps: Handy Presets”

  • Zen Master (barely interrupts)

  • Debugger (code‑focused)

  • Drama Queen (expressive needs)

All presets come from the README. Add them to ~/.zshrc / ~/.bashrc to take effect.

5) Troubleshooting & Uninstall

Section titled “5) Troubleshooting & Uninstall”
  • Can’t see the pet? Restart Claude Code and check statusLine in ~/.claude/settings.json.
  • Commands not working? Ensure /pet-* files exist in ~/.claude/commands/; check bun --version if you’re using Bun.
  • Uninstall? Remove ~/.claude/commands/pet-*.md, clean up ~/.claude/pets/*.json, and delete the statusLine config.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Work needs efficiency, your mind needs care. This little pet won’t write code for you, but it brings back a bit of “human warmth” to collaborating with AI. Install it and give it two days. You might start to enjoy being “seen while coding.” (As of 2025-08-15, the project has about 36⭐ and is being updated rapidly.)

item.title: Station: Unified Management for Claude/Cursor Agents
item.content:encoded:
Want a self‑hosted, versionable, packable agent runtime so the “mini‑agents” you build in Claude Code or Cursor can actually go live? Station was built exactly for that.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

The tool called Station has been making the rounds lately. It’s not yet another “application‑level” agent platform. Instead, it’s a lightweight runtime and packaging/distribution system purpose‑built for deployable sub‑agents. In one sentence: take the “small but capable agents” you create in Claude Code or Cursor, then package them, ship to production, connect permissions, audit every run, and manage versions cleanly.

Highlights at a Glance (Built for Internal Use)

Section titled “Highlights at a Glance (Built for Internal Use)”

Why Station? Because internal automation isn’t a normal app: you need secrets, database access, CI/CD, and auditability.

  • Internal‑task first: Sub‑agents can read production databases (with proper controls), monitor infrastructure, drive CI/CD, run security scans, and handle incident response.
  • Security built‑in: Self‑hosted, secret encryption (AES), multi‑environment isolation (dev/staging/prod), and full audit trails.
  • Lightweight and pluggable: A single ~45MB binary with local SQLite out of the box; switch to PostgreSQL in production; natural GitOps (config is versionable).
  • MCP‑native: Acts directly as an MCP runtime, reusing your team‑approved MCP tools (filesystem, Slack, AWS, K8s, DB, and more).
  • Great DX: A Genkit‑powered browser playground plus stn develop for visualizing tool calls and execution flows.

What’s MCP? In short, it’s a unified protocol for letting LLMs use “controlled tools.” Claude Desktop’s official tutorial includes a quickstart and configuration examples.

How Does Station Work?

Section titled “How Does Station Work?”

The core structure is simple: One .prompt file + a set of MCP tools = a deployable sub‑agent. Environments are organized as dev/staging/prod. Tool definitions live in template.json; environment variables in variables.yml. Finally, everything can be bundled and installed elsewhere.

Installation and Integration (Up and Running in 5 Minutes)

2) Infra Health Checks / Cost Dashboards (AWS cost)

Section titled “2) Infra Health Checks / Cost Dashboards (AWS cost)”
  • Goal: Pull the last 7 days of AWS costs, generate a daily report, and send it via Slack.
  • How: Combine AWS cost tools + Slack; output Markdown on a schedule.
  • Value: Turn “AI + cloud cost” into a steady rhythm your team can rely on.

3) CI/CD Deployment Automation (containers/K8s)

Section titled “3) CI/CD Deployment Automation (containers/K8s)”
  • Goal: For a small release, run docker exec + kubectl apply, and write back the change‑request link.
  • How: Combine Docker MCP + Kubernetes MCP; deployments become one‑sentence operations.
  • Value: Humans speak intention; agents do the grunt work.

4) Read‑only Prod DB Checks / Slow SQL Sampling

Section titled “4) Read‑only Prod DB Checks / Slow SQL Sampling”
  • Goal: Connect to production (read‑only credentials), sample slow queries and index hits.
  • How: Combine DB MCP with custom analysis scripts.
  • Value: Inspect issues close to the source to cut down back‑and‑forth firefighting.

5) Code‑Review Bot (with internal rules)

Section titled “5) Code‑Review Bot (with internal rules)”
  • Goal: Produce review suggestions aligned with team rules (security/performance/style).
  • How: Define scoring dimensions and output format in .prompt; attach filesystem MCP to read code; emit structured suggestions.
  • Value: Productize “coding standards” for consistent enforcement.

How It Differs from App‑Style Agent Platforms

Section titled “How It Differs from App‑Style Agent Platforms”
  • Station targets tasks that “enter your intranet and require permissions and auditing.”
  • Emphasis on self‑hosting and data sovereignty.
  • The single‑binary + SQLite lightweight form makes it feel like an ops tool, not a platform.

You can also treat Station as an MCP “hub.” It can consume other MCP servers, and also expose MCP tools to others for “list agents / create agents / invoke agents.”

Rollout Checklist (Team Adoption)

Section titled “Rollout Checklist (Team Adoption)”
  • Secret management: Store keys and connection strings in Station’s encrypted vault, isolated per environment.
  • Least privilege: Equip each sub‑agent with only the MCP tools it needs — less is more.
  • GitOps: Put template.json, .prompt, and variables.yml in git; land via MR and then cut a release.
  • Audit trails: Every execution has a trace; incidents are fully reconstructable.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Station turns those “small, capable agents” from ideas discussed at your desktop into deployable, auditable, and replicable internal automation. No need to wrangle another platform — write a good .prompt, attach the right tools, and ship the bundle to production. That’s what I like most about it: simple, controlled, and easy to propagate.

item.title: Claude Code on a Budget
item.content:encoded:
Trim conversations, pick the right model, lock down permissions — and your Claude Code bill can drop by half.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Many teams use Claude Code and feel “budget pain” every month. It’s not that you typed too much — it’s the invisible token sink eating the bill. The good news: you can control it, and the effect is immediate.

This guide breaks cost‑saving into three tiers: basic, intermediate, advanced. Follow them and you’ll save the bulk of your spend.

I. Where Does the Money Go? 4 “Token Sinks”

Section titled “I. Where Does the Money Go? 4 “Token Sinks””

1) Invisible context from system and memory Claude Code automatically loads the system prompt and layered CLAUDE.md memory (org/project/user). This content enters context on every turn, naturally consuming tokens.**

2) Big price gaps across models Official pricing: Sonnet 4 ≈ $3/$15 per million input/output tokens; Opus 4/4.1 ≈ $15/$75. For the same conversation, switching models means ~5× unit price.**

3) Context gets fatter as you chat Claude Code supports very large contexts (Sonnet 4 up to 1M tokens in testing). Longer chats trigger auto‑compression and repeated “setup”, making tokens fly.**

4) Background and noise spending Beyond visible replies, /cost queries, auto‑summaries, Haiku prompts, etc., also burn small amounts of tokens. Pennies add up.**

Summary: It’s not that you ask too much — it’s that “everything gets hauled on stage every time.”

II. Three Tiers of Savings (Use Now)

Section titled “II. Three Tiers of Savings (Use Now)”

A. Basics: 4 Moves Everyone Should Use

Section titled “A. Basics: 4 Moves Everyone Should Use”

  • Manual slimming beats passive compression Use /compact proactively, and add a focus directive:

    Auto‑compression triggers near 95% capacity — waiting is too late.**

  • One task per thread; clear when done Start a new session for each small task; once finished, run /clear to avoid a ballooning history.**

  • Pick the right default model Use Sonnet 4 for day‑to‑day development. When you truly hit “hard/long/deep reasoning,” switch to Opus via /model. You can also use “Opus for planning + Sonnet for execution” — stronger planning, cheaper execution.**

  • Check the bill anytime In any session, run /cost to see current spend; teams can check history in the console and set workspace spend limits.**

Figure idea (illustration 2:1 | English copy) “A developer squeezing a giant chat bubble into a slim pill, while a tiny receipt shows shrinking token numbers.”

B. Intermediate: Tighten the Flow, Shrink the Bill

Section titled “B. Intermediate: Tighten the Flow, Shrink the Bill”

  • Docs‑first to prevent context blowups First have Claude produce a “TODO list / brief plan,” confirm, then execute. Iterate in Plan Mode (planning mode); confirm and switch back to execution.**

  • Put “long‑term memory” into CLAUDE.md Put standards, common commands, and project conventions into CLAUDE.md; next time it applies automatically. Use /memory to edit quickly in a chat when needed. Memory loads by layer automatically, reducing the tokens you spend “repeating yourself.”**

  • Small commits, easy to roll back Ask Claude to produce a commit message after each small chunk. If something goes wrong, roll back — fewer wrong turns means fewer tokens. (Engineering practice)

  • Team rate‑limits & flight instruments Set sane TPM (tokens per minute) based on org size to avoid costly concurrency “meltdowns.”**

C. Advanced: Hard‑Core Cost Downs (Biggest Gains)

Section titled “C. Advanced: Hard‑Core Cost Downs (Biggest Gains)”

1) Permission allow/deny lists to stop “random file reads” Use /permissions + .claude/settings.json to forbid logs, binaries, and huge directories, and allow only necessary paths. Rules support gitignore patterns.**

Note: plan mode analyzes without changing files; read/write rules shrink the file surface — less scanning = fewer tokens.**

2) Be precise to “lines,” not whole files Don’t paste entire blocks. Provide file path + target line ranges + 5 key bullets to minimize irrelevant scanning. (Engineering practice)

3) Model split: let Opus handle only the “expensive parts” In /model, use Opus for plans/architecture/cross‑module dependency analysis; hand off code generation and fixes to Sonnet. This is the recommended direction from official guidance.**

4) (Team/Gateway) Use Prompt Caching For API or enterprise gateways, prompt caching saves visibly on repeated large prefixes. Official pricing offers cheaper write/hit rates for cached prompts.**

III. Ready‑to‑Use Cost‑Saving Checklist

Section titled “III. Ready‑to‑Use Cost‑Saving Checklist”
  • Default to Sonnet; switch to Opus only when needed: flip with /model.**
  • Keep Plan Mode on by default: plan first, execute after confirmation.**
  • Start every session by slimming: /compact Focus on code diffs and test failures.**
  • Close the loop with /clear: prevent ever‑growing history.**
  • Strict permissions: use /permissions and readRules/editRules to restrict directories and types.**
  • Audit anytime: /cost + console “workspace spend limit.”**
  • Write memory into CLAUDE.md: reduce repeated priming and context stuffing.**

IV. Real Savings: Why These Work

Section titled “IV. Real Savings: Why These Work”
  • Unit price spread: Opus costs about 5× Sonnet. Concentrate “expensive thinking” in planning; use Sonnet for execution — total cost drops significantly.**
  • Size costs: auto‑loaded memory + long threads fatten context; proactive /compact and /clear shrink transfer volume directly.**
  • Less irrelevant I/O: permissions and rules act as a cost firewall, blocking large, low‑value dirs/files.**
  • Background overhead under control: knowing what “quietly spends” helps you avoid pointless refreshes and queries.**

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Claude Code’s power comes from “bringing everything along.” The key to saving is to bring only what’s necessary.

Apply this checklist to your project today: start with /model, /compact, /clear, then add CLAUDE.md and permission rules. By month’s end, your bill should surprise you — in a good way.

What do you think? What other money pits have you hit? Share in the comments.
